title: Monday, 4th December, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Off we go then. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever.

BE11:04am

BE11:04am

Seasonal appeal auction time!

11:03 am
BE11:04am

http://stores.ebay...zheimersresearchuk

BE11:06am

Some cracking lots this year. Lunch with MSW .... a tour with Robin Lane Fox of some Oxford college I'd probably recognise if they'd let me in .... a quinquepod of commentariat.

BE11:07am

You can also join Hugh Carnegy trying to get the paper off slate while I file 20 minutes late then moan about the headline.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

However, my insider tip here is: https://www.ebay.c...dges-/112664995430

BE11:08am

YOU GET A £1k SELFRIDGES GIFT CARD

BE11:08am

Bidding is currently at £250

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Suggesting a value on Jo Ellison's fashion advice of 25p in the pound. Which is quite, quite, quite wrong.

BE11:09am

Be generous, readers. If any of the ROTR end up winning a lot, we at team AV might even buy you a pint.

BE11:09am

(Not a binding offer.)

11:09 am
undefined
BE11:10am

Okay, so let's get on.

BE11:11am

FTSE drifting higher largely on the US tax thing you'll have spent all weekend reading about, in between all the articles about Bitcoin.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

US exposure's in favour.

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 1,965, up 61 (+3.20%), High: 1,977, Low: 1,940, Volume: 454.23k
Carnival PLC (CCL:LSE): Last: 4,921, up 157 (+3.30%), High: 4,928, Low: 4,807, Volume: 193.00k
11:11 am
CRH PLC (CRH:LSE): Last: 2,599, up 52 (+2.04%), High: 2,618, Low: 2,586, Volume: 905.75k
BE11:12am

And below that we have Sky.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 955.50, up 25.5 (+2.74%), High: 956.00, Low: 943.50, Volume: 1.49m
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Disney reportedly restarts talks with Fox, with the latter looking to dump entertainment assets including its 39% stake in Sky.

BE11:13am

https://www.ft.com...-a039-c64b1c09b482

BE11:13am

If a deal is agreed, Fox will ditch the Sky bid and Disney will bid instead. That's the idea here.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Course, it ain't that easy.

BE11:13am

Takeover Panel rules mean a bidder can't just walk away without express approval from the Panel or a mutual agreement between bidder and target.

BE11:14am

Which was the oil company caught out by that about five years ago? Bid when oil was $80 then tried to pull out when oil was $40, but couldn't.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, the safety net here is that if Disney (or anyone else) buys 39% of Sky there's a mandatory for the rest.

BE11:15am

Which, according to UBS, "is likely it will have to be on the same terms as the Fox offer. "

BE11:16am

[W]e think Sky is strategically interesting to a range of bidders, particularly if it is part of a broader deal for Fox's entertainment assets and this should limit the downside for Sky. Specifically, we think Sky is attractive given its scale in content (£7bn pa programming budget with £1bn pa on original programming) and direct-to-consumer distribution with Sky going pan-European recently launching OTT in Spain/Switzerland.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

The CMA is due to give provisional findings on its phase two investigation into the Fox/Sky deal from 18 December onwards. We note Ofcom was unequivocal in its phase one review of the deal that there were no issues on broadcasting standards and was willing to accept remedies on media plurality where Fox offered safeguards on the independence of editorial for Sky News and its funding. We note the Fox/Sky deal was cleared with on competition grounds by the EC with only a phase one review (three months) and it is likely a deal for Sky by Disney, or another strategic bidder, could be approved relatively quickly. Other bidders for Sky would not have the same issues as Fox on cross media ownership in the UK or Fox News.

BE11:18am

While on Sky, should also note the BT report from Nick over the weekend.

BE11:18am

https://www.ft.com...ce08b24dc#comments

11:18 am
BE11:18am

BT is heading into a critical auction of UK Premier League rights with far less of a strut than when it first elbowed its way into the sports market four years ago.

Having spent £3.8bn on football rights since 2012, it has publicly checked its aggression ahead of the next auction, expected to kick off in February, which will decide who shows the 2019 to 2022 seasons.

BE11:19am

“We have a Plan B,” [Gavin Patterson] told a Morgan Stanley investor conference in Barcelona two weeks ago. “We are never in a situation where it is existential for us.”

He said the group’s ambition was to retain its position as a “strong number two” behind Sky in pay-TV sports.

BE11:20am

Don't think I've ever heard of a company describe its target as being a “strong number two" ......

11:21 am
BE11:21am

........ particularly in what we used to call TMT, where the "first or nowhere" thing is dominant.

undefined
BE11:23am

(@urgeview: it was Imperial Energy! Thank you!)

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Elsewhere in M&A, albeit rather further down the market .....

BE11:23am

Elegant Hotels.

BE11:23am

As reported by Dominic Walsh of the Times, who is by some distance the leisure sector's best reporter.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

https://www.thetim...edfellow-gbpzrxnd5

BE11:24am

Melia offered 110p a share, Dom reports.

BE11:24am

But alas, it's DOA.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

https://www.invest...1712040750502548Y/

BE11:24am

The Board of Elegant Hotels announces that it had received an approach from Melia Hotels International SA "Melia Hotels" relating to a possible all cash offer for all of the issued and to be issued share capital of the Company which may be made by Melia Hotels or one of its investment affiliates. The Company further announces that discussions with Melia Hotels have now been terminated, and that Melia Hotels does not intend to make an offer to acquire the entire issued and to be issued ordinary share capital of Elegant Hotels.

BE11:25am

This all seems to have happened very quickly.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Which might strike folk as a wee bit odd, since rumours were reaching us a full nine months ago that Elegant Hotels was attracting interest.

BE11:25am

We noted those rumours here.

BE11:25am

https://www.ft.com...417ee6c76#comments

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Aim-listed Elegant Hotels added 1.5 per cent to 86.5p amid rumours that two potential bidders have been circling the Barbados resort owner.

BE11:25am

And also here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-04-03/

BE11:25am

And also here: https://www.ft.com...-9d7c-be108f1c1dce

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Now, I guess that could've been idle and totally unrelated speculation.

BE11:03am

Let's get the plug up first.

Elegant Hotels Group PLC (EHG:LSE): Last: 83.50, no change, Volume: 90.01k
11:28 am
BE11:29am

Have some sellside. Liberum's joint shop with ..... let me check ..... oh, Zeus Capital.

BE11:29am

The proposed bid that was reported in the press this weekend was at a rumoured £100m. On our calculations this puts the offer at a discount to NAV and our NAV is very prudent indeed. This was highly opportunistic in our view and truly does show just how cheap the Group is in our view. Trading has been strong and in line with expectations (last trading update 12 October), the shares offer an 8.4% dividend yield, and are currently valued at a c.40% discount to our NAV calculation. The market share the group commands on Barbados, its sales & marketing office and its significant asset-backing all support a much higher valuation let alone the opportunity to see material earnings upgrades over the next few years.

BE11:29am

And Canaccord, not shop.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Elegant Hotels plans to be a consolidator in the Caribbean luxury hotel sector. We believe there is a real opportunity for Elegant Hotels to take market share with its branded offer in a region where ownership tends to be fragmented. It has capable management and execution is good; however, mostly due to Brexit, its balance sheet is no longer in the best shape and this is hampering its prospects at a time when it should be accelerating its growth. We believe Elegant Hotels needs to refinance its debt where it can, cut the dividend to a more sensible level and get back on the acquisition trail. It can be difficult for a company to cut its dividend because of how this action can be interpreted, but an 8% yield suggests a cut has been factored in by the market. Indeed, a 'reboot' should act as a positive catalyst to close the gap to our target price.

BE11:30am

Elegant Hotels trades on easily the lowest multiples of our peer group. We believe that the current share price fails to take into account: (1) the underlying asset valuation underpinning the group; we calculate that Elegant Hotels is trading at a c.50% discount to adjusted NAV/share of US$2.41/185p using current valuations; (2) the possibility of a bid from a rival hotel operator (Elegant Resorts possibly), private equity or property developer attracted to the NAV discount; or (3) the opportunity to ‘reboot’ the balance sheet to allow the company to return to the acquisition trail. Our 110p target price is based on a 13x PE, 10.0x EV/EBITDA, a 10% FCF yield for FY18E and a 40% discount to adjusted NAV (arguably too much).

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:31am

So, sterling's done a flip on Barnier saying he sees a Brexit breakthrough as likely today.

BE11:31am

Cable now nudging $1.35, FTSE hit in response.

BE11:34am

Good luck trading this. Good luck trading the secondary effects of politicians giving interviews not in their first language about things that might happen later in private meetings.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:34am

Back we go then. Few bits of sellside to mention.

BE11:35am

Merrill on Ultra Electronics, for instance.

11:35 am
Ultra Electronics Holdings PLC (ULE:LSE): Last: 1,264, down 36 (-2.77%), High: 1,284, Low: 1,252, Volume: 203.00k
BE11:35am

(@red: in that case, your bid in the charity auction ought to be huge with all that easy money you're making.)

BE11:36am

We downgrade Ultra Electronics to an Underperform rating, with a PO of 1250p. We take a more cautious view on midterm organic growth, given growing concerns around UK MoD budget pressures. We lower our 2018-19 estimates by 10% and lower our PO to 1250p.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

That's the upshot there. Also, on the fallers, Drax.

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 259.20, down 9.9 (-3.68%), High: 271.20, Low: 257.60, Volume: 500.04k
BE11:37am

HSBC turning cautious.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Drax’s investment proposition is based primarily on its government-supported renewable and capacity-payment supported generation. In addition, we see an opportunity for deploying its biomass and coal plant to achieve premium pricing in periods of increased demand and provide balancing services to compensate for intermittent generation. RTE, the French network operator, and EDF have reported a series of planned and unplanned outages in EDF’s UK and French nuclear fleet at present. On 1 December 2017, UK net demand for power was 47GW. The UK was exporting 2GW of power to France, 0.2GW to Holland, and 0.5GW to Ireland. 9.2GW of coal was on the system, meeting 19% of total demand, gas met 48% of demand, nuclear 13% of demand, and solar and wind 10% of demand. Drax’s biomass units were generating 2GW, meeting 4% of demand. The difficulty we have is assuming how much of these high demand and premium-priced opportunities will contribute to 2018 profits. Because of our caution we lower our 2018 EPS estimates by 36%. Weather in Q1 could be a swing factor to or estimates.

BE11:38am

290p target.

BE11:39am

Down from 360p.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:42am

Urg, they're talking about bitcoin over there again.

BE11:43am

Where are we now? Still around 11,000? Or is it back down to 10,000 articles a minute?

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Regarding CGT, my understanding is that if you class your crypto tokens as a speculative position then HMRC considers it akin to any other kind of gambling and you pay no tax.

BE11:45am

If, however, you use your crypto tokens to buy drugs or whatever then it's no longer a gambling position and you should be paying tax.

BE11:45am

Though I don't know if "buy drugs or whatever" is on many tax disclosure forms.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

The only observation I'll make on Bitcoin is it's not a damn currency,

BE11:46am

Stop calling it a currency. It confuses people. It's not a currency. It's a protocol.

BE11:47am

And as a protocol it doesn't matter a single damn whether the price quoted is $1 or $1,000,000. It makes no difference whatsoever to its only usage (which, let's face it, is to buy drugs or whatever) because it's just a transfer mechanism.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Anyway, have this: http://www.telegra...dering-tax-dodging

BE11:49am

It gets very fuzzy over the difference between an exchange and a wallet and doesn't really touch on how European AML laws affect companies outside the EU, such as -- random example! -- San Fransisco based Coinbase.

BE11:49am

But, hey, it's always nice to hear politicians talk on the record about stuff they barely understand.

11:49 am
undefined
BE11:50am

Few other things to touch on before we wrap up.

BE11:51am

Sorry, @Bonceur I think it was ... have nothing to hand that's strategic and top-down on equity vol.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

And sorry, H1, ditto Dixons.

BE11:52am

So instead, here's Barclays saying you should buy IQE.

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 170.25, up 6.5 (+3.97%), High: 176.50, Low: 167.25, Volume: 4.10m
11:52 am
BE11:52am

We expand our European Technology Hardware coverage by initiating with an Overweight rating on IQE. Our 210p price target is based on P/E, cross-checked against a DCF analysis. At our price target, the shares would trade on 33x/26x 2019E/20E P/E, premium multiples but ones we argue are well supported by the near- 40% compound growth in EPS we model through 2020E.

BE11:53am

As the world’s leading supplier of epitaxial wafers, we find IQE very well positioned within the compound semiconductor ecosystem, enabling it to benefit from structural growth in photonics (including 3D sensing/VCSELs) and power semis (including auto EVs). Its strong and steady market share in epiwafers for RF power amplifiers give it, in our opinion, a solid base from which to target such growth opportunities.
In the near term, we view the most exciting part of the IQE story as the growth driven by VCSELs, in particular for 3D sensing. IQE is the only supplier manufacturing 6” epiwafers for mass market VCSELs and we estimate it to have full share of the current iPhone X-driven ramp. The complexity of manufacturing wafers for VCSEL production (300-400 epitaxial layers vs. 12-14 for RF applications) suggests competition will take time to bridge the gap. Our ahead-of-consensus revenue forecasts for the next few years are based on the view that 3D sensing will grow strongly from here (see our proprietary model) and IQE will sustain near full share through 2018 and into 2019.

BE11:53am

This strong growth in Photonics and expected steady trends in Wireless are the key drivers of our forecasts. Due to the higher complexity, Photonics wafers are priced higher and have higher margins, resulting in a positive gross margin mix shift as we forecast Photonics to grow faster. IQE is growing opex in order to support such growth and invest in future technologies, but operating leverage leads us to forecast margins expanding from 15% in 2017E to 23% in 2020E. Combined with our 21% revenue CAGR through 2020E, operating leverage leads to a 37% CAGR in EPS to 2020E.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

IQE shares have performed well in 2017 (+359% vs. Euro Stoxx Tech +20%), owing to excitement over the ramp in VCSEL demand, as well as raised awareness over the long-term potential for compound semis and the relatively consolidated epitaxial wafer market for such applications. Despite such recent performance, we think we are only at the beginning of this multi-year structural trend, within which we expect IQE to be a key player. In the near term, we anticipate a trading update in December or early January, which we expect to provide a positive update on demand. In our view, such strong growth and likely estimate momentum support premium multiples. With the shares trading on 27x/22x 2019E/20E P/E for 37% compound EPS growth through 2020E, we consider the shares very attractive. We initiate with an Overweight rating and a 210p price target, implying c.20% upside potential from current levels.

BE11:55am

That follows some fun with IQE on Friday, after Digitimes picked up something in the Chinese media about wafer orders.

BE11:57am

We mentioned in the paper on Saturday, but didn't have room to quote the full Stifel note that was in response to the report that picked up the other report. So let's address that here.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

We believe recent press speculation (source: Digitimes) suggesting that IQE is to be pushed out of wafer supply to Lumentum for the iPhone X is most likely inaccurate. The perceived shift of supply to Taiwanese based Epistar seems to be mistaking 6” VCSEL epi supply with 4” LED epi supply – there is more than a degree of difficulty that separates the two and more so at scale. We make three points that investors should bear in mind when reading this kind of speculation (i) If Epistar was a scale VCSEL epitaxy supplier we would have seen numerous reports of their process qualification and subsequent OEM engagement for at least a year now (give or take), (ii) there are public announcements from IQE outlining multiple, multi-year epitaxy contracts with customers and the protection associated with these contracts is unlikely to be undermined within the first year, and (iii) we question the sometimes sporadic track record of the journal source and certainly on this occasion. Overall, we continue to think IQE is well-positioned to be the scale player in the production of 6” epi wafers for the manufacturing of VCSELs through to 2019-20 at least.

BE11:59am

I think, also, that IQE management's on a roadshow right now if you want to hear more about VCSEL epitaxy wafers.

BE11:59am

Speaking personally, I'm not sure I do.

11:59 am
undefined
BE12:00pm

Okay, I'm done.

BE12:00pm

That's enough, right? That's plenty for a Monday.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Let's close this and get on with our lives.

BE12:02pm

Go bid in the auction. Be generous with all that hard-earned CryptoKittie cash you're making. And see you tomorrow.

BE12:02pm

(@Tom: is that a euphemism?)

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Does feel a tiny bit strange though, to hear the detail of the long-rumoured bid over the weekend and have it collapse by the Monday.
